repnme.cdata!:
Vanuatu - Learning and Innovation Credit
            for Second Eduction Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Education Project for Vanuatu
            was expected to pilot-test whether Vanuatu could effectively
            deliver a package of innovations intended to help the
            country move towards its objective of Education for All,
            defined as formal basic education of good quality. The
            reasons stated by the Government of Vanuatu for the deferral
            of the signature deadline included: (i) concerns over the
            vernacular language issue as the Project's main focus;
            (ii) the experimental nature of the Project design; (iii)
            the need for a more system-wide approach for building on
            Vanuatu's Education for All agenda; (iv) the
            government's capacity to meet counterpart funding
            requirements; (v) uncertainty over the scale and scope of
            the Credit, including that it might be the precursor to a
            much larger IDA involvement; and (vi) concern that an
            unacceptably large proportion of funds were to meet the cost
            of international technical assistance.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Education
            Project (Learning and Innovation Loan) is to identify an
            efficient, replicable, and sustainable model that provides
            instruction in vernacular languages and in English and
            French, in rural areas of Vanuatu. Specifically, the project
            pilot-tests whether Vanuatu can effectively deliver a
            package of innovations intended to help the country move
            toward its objective of Education for All, defined as formal
            basic education of good quality through year 8. There are
            two main project components. The first comprises five
            sub-components: It expands access to primary school and
            increases educational quality by improving community
            participation through annual community consultations, and
            enlisting community support to construct or repair
            pre-schools, repair primary-year classrooms, and construct
            housing for community secondary school teachers. This
            component also strengthens collaborative relationships with
            parents, teachers, and other community members to upgrade
            educational quality; partners with nongovernmental
            organizations to operate pre-schools in pilot communities;
            provides educational equipment and learning materials; and
            builds community secondary schools. The second component
            funds capacity enhancement with technical assistance for
            vernacular language development, curriculum development,
            teacher training, and project and sector management, the
            latter to include policy and program studies, school
            mapping, and site and facility surveys.
